<|ref|>title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 121, 636, 145]]<|/det|> # Cambridge International AS & A Level <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 170, 195, 201]]<|/det|> CANDIDATE NAME <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 221, 175, 250]]<|/det|> CENTRE NUMBER <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[210, 211, 425, 260]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[620, 220, 720, 250]]<|/det|> CANDIDATE NUMBER <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[735, 211, 905, 256]]<|/det|> <|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 277, 178, 293]]<|/det|> ## PHYSICS <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[832, 277, 905, 293]]<|/det|> 9702/31 <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 301, 359, 317]]<|/det|> Paper 3 Advanced Practical Skills 1 <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[707, 301, 905, 317]]<|/det|> October/November 2022 <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[841, 326, 905, 341]]<|/det|> 2 hours <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 355, 393, 371]]<|/det|> You must answer on the question paper. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 384, 700, 401]]<|/det|> You will need: The materials and apparatus listed in the confidential instructions <|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 419, 230, 435]]<|/det|> ## INSTRUCTIONS <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 435, 285, 450]]<|/det|> Answer all questions. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 450, 808, 467]]<|/det|> Use a black or dark blue pen. You may use an HB pencil for any diagrams or graphs. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 466, 808, 482]]<|/det|> Write your name, centre number and candidate number in the boxes at the top of the page. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 482, 562, 497]]<|/det|> Write your answer to each question in the space provided. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 498, 480, 512]]<|/det|> Do not use an erasable pen or correction fluid. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 513, 359, 527]]<|/det|> Do not write on any bar codes. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 528, 798, 544]]<|/det|> You will be allowed to work with the apparatus for a maximum of 1 hour for each question. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 544, 892, 575]]<|/det|> You should record all your observations in the spaces provided in the question paper as soon as these observations are made. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 575, 320, 590]]<|/det|> You may use a calculator. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 590, 578, 606]]<|/det|> You should show all your working and use appropriate units. <|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 635, 220, 650]]<|/det|> ## INFORMATION <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 651, 384, 666]]<|/det|> The total mark for this paper is 40. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 667, 729, 682]]<|/det|> The number of marks for each question or part question is shown in brackets [ ]. <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[710, 732, 905, 860]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[386, 868, 611, 884]]<|/det|> This document has 12 pages.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[260, 72, 737, 89]]<|/det|>
**You may not need to use all of the materials provided.**

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 102, 96, 120]]<|/det|>
<label>1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 102, 660, 120]]<|/det|>
In this experiment, you will investigate oscillations of card shapes.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 133, 146, 151]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 133, 668, 151]]<|/det|>
You have been provided with a circular card of radius 10.0 cm.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 164, 180, 182]]<|/det|>
<label>•</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 164, 717, 182]]<|/det|>
Draw a circle on the card of radius 9.0 cm, as shown in Fig. 1.1.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[316, 193, 680, 373]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[406, 387, 591, 405]]<|/det|>
Fig. 1.1 (not to scale)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 419, 175, 437]]<|/det|>
<label>•</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 419, 920, 452]]<|/det|>
Fold the card in half. Cut carefully along the line, as shown in Fig. 1.2, and keep both parts of the card.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[228, 458, 766, 618]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[408, 631, 591, 649]]<|/det|>
Fig. 1.2 (not to scale)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 73, 173, 88]]<|/det|>
<label>•</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 72, 920, 106]]<|/det|>
The distance between the centre of one side of the card shape and the centre of the other side is \(d\), as shown in Fig. 1.3.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[237, 112, 759, 255]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[463, 270, 534, 288]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 1.3</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 301, 384, 319]]<|/det|>
Measure and record \(d\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[551, 348, 920, 366]]<|/det|>
<form>d = .................................................... [1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 380, 146, 397]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 380, 492, 397]]<|/det|>
Stand the card shape on the bench.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 411, 175, 428]]<|/det|>
<label>•</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 410, 920, 444]]<|/det|>
Adjust the loops of card until the distance between the points where the loops touch the bench is approximately \(3\mathrm{cm}\), as shown in Fig. 1.4.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[203, 450, 792, 618]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[463, 636, 534, 654]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 1.4</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 668, 176, 685]]<|/det|>
<label>•</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 667, 920, 700]]<|/det|>
Gently press down one side of the card shape through a short distance. Release the card shape so that it oscillates.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 714, 176, 731]]<|/det|>
<label>•</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 713, 559, 731]]<|/det|>
Determine the period \(T\) of these oscillations.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[554, 841, 920, 860]]<|/det|>
<form>T = ............................................................ [2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 144, 90]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 72, 920, 104]]<|/det|>
Use the remaining card to cut out shapes of smaller radius, each with the same width of \(1.0 \text{cm}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 102, 920, 135]]<|/det|>
For each card shape, measure \(d\) and repeat **(b)**. Repeat until you have five sets of values of \(d\) and \(T\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 149, 688, 168]]<|/det|>
Record your results in a table. Include values of \(T^2\) in your table.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 490, 920, 508]]<|/det|>
<mark>[8]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 520, 144, 539]]<|/det|>
<label>(d)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 520, 175, 539]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 520, 650, 539]]<|/det|>
Plot a graph of \(T^2\) on the \(y\)-axis against \(d\) on the \(x\)-axis.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 520, 920, 539]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 551, 180, 570]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 551, 457, 570]]<|/det|>
Draw the straight line of best fit.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 551, 920, 570]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[144, 581, 180, 600]]<|/det|>
<label>(iii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 581, 608, 600]]<|/det|>
Determine the gradient and \(y\)-intercept of this line.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[494, 784, 917, 801]]<|/det|>
<form>gradient = ........................................................

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[475, 815, 917, 833]]<|/det|>
<form>y-intercept = ..........................................................

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 831, 920, 848]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[260, 72, 740, 89]]<|/det|>
You may not need to use all of the materials provided.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 103, 97, 121]]<|/det|>
<label>2</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 102, 690, 120]]<|/det|>
In this experiment, you will investigate the collision of two pendulums.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 134, 144, 152]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 134, 183, 152]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[185, 134, 918, 166]]<|/det|>
Mould the two pieces of modelling clay onto the ends of the **shorter** strings to make two pendulums, as shown in Fig. 2.1.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[160, 175, 834, 312]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[467, 326, 536, 344]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 2.1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 357, 219, 375]]<|/det|>
<label>•</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[235, 357, 584, 375]]<|/det|>
Set up the apparatus as shown in Fig. 2.2.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[196, 384, 764, 688]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[465, 699, 534, 717]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 2.2</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 730, 218, 747]]<|/det|>
<label>•</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[232, 730, 841, 747]]<|/det|>
Adjust the modelling clay until the lengths of the pendulums are the same.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 761, 213, 778]]<|/det|>
<label>•</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[232, 761, 920, 794]]<|/det|>
The distance between the bottom of the wooden blocks and the centre of the smaller piece of modelling clay is \(l\), as shown in Fig. 2.2.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[232, 807, 418, 824]]<|/det|>
Measure and record \(l\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[561, 852, 920, 870]]<|/det|>
<form>l = .................................................... [1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 144, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 72, 183, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[188, 72, 212, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>●</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[230, 72, 920, 106]]<|/det|>
Hold the larger pendulum so the horizontal distance between the centres of the pendulums is \(p\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 117, 725, 136]]<|/det|>
Release the larger pendulum so that the pendulums collide.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 149, 920, 183]]<|/det|>
After colliding, the maximum angle between the vertical and the string of the **smaller** pendulum is \(\theta\), as shown in Fig. 2.4.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[376, 191, 616, 458]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[463, 467, 534, 486]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 2.4</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[230, 498, 423, 515]]<|/det|>
Measure and record \(\theta\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[554, 668, 920, 686]]<|/det|>
<form>\(\theta =\) .................................................... °

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 700, 181, 718]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 700, 813, 718]]<|/det|>
Estimate the percentage uncertainty in your value of \(\theta\). Show your working.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[376, 839, 920, 857]]<|/det|>
<form>percentage uncertainty = .................................................... %

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[892, 839, 920, 857]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 144, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>(e)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 72, 609, 89]]<|/det|>
It is suggested that the relationship between \(\theta\) and \(R\) is

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[415, 102, 584, 120]]<|/det|>
\[k(1 - \cos \theta) = 1 - R\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 134, 339, 151]]<|/det|>
where \(k\) is a constant.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 165, 507, 182]]<|/det|>
Using your data, calculate two values of \(k\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[448, 350, 917, 368]]<|/det|>
<form>first value of \(k =\) ........................................................

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[418, 381, 920, 399]]<|/det|>
<form>second value of \(k =\) ........................................................

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 396, 920, 415]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 428, 141, 446]]<|/det|>
<label>(f)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 428, 751, 445]]<|/det|>
It is suggested that the percentage uncertainty in the values of \(k\) is \(10\%\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 458, 826, 477]]<|/det|>
Using this uncertainty, explain whether your results support the relationship in **(e)**.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[853, 675, 920, 694]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 72, 183, 89]]<|/det|>
